I have planned three milestones for the development of lean4-mode. You can find more details on Github: https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean4-mode/milestones

The first milestone will focus on repairing the library headers, Github workflows and documentation.

The second milestone will do some basic internal cleanup of the Elisp code. "Internal" in the sense that these changes should be perceivable for most end-users.

The third milestone comes with breaking changes. It aims to remove the hard dependency on lsp-mode. Ideally, end-users would be allowed to choose between lsp-mode and Eglot. Let's see how that goes. @David Thrane Christiansen had mentioned some problems with Eglot. In particular, we will have to see if we port the Lean4 Info View to Eglot or if we use the less feature-rich ElDoc when the end-user chooses Eglot instead of lsp-mode. As you can see, this milestone is not yet completely planned and we can discuss many things. Maybe we'll even split it into two milestones instead. Let's see how it goes.

Hi all. I'd like to hear your opinion! Several upcoming changes to Lean4-Mode will be breaking changes:

  • Prefix all symbols and files with lean4-mode-.
  • A deep refactor of all files and in particular, get rid of lean4-settings.el file and the lean4-keybinding-* user options.
  • Support both Eglot and lsp-mode.

Breaking changes are cumbersome for users. Should we merge all these changes onto a "dev" branch and release them all together in a single breaking release?
I suggest that we create a tag for a version "just before breaking changes" and add a paragraph to README saying that master may have breaking changes compared to the latest version.
Users who want to use a stable version can use the tagged version then.
Mekeor Melire has marked this topic as resolved.
